response.answer_text: No, not really. Or at least not directly so. We map and survey everything to a world grid that is north and south and east and west precisely. But magnetic compasses align themselves with the earth’s magnetic field, which is not at all aligned with the earth. The difference between the north seeking needle and actual north is called variation, and every area on the earth has had this error determined and is marked on local maps. In fact it slowly drifts a bit over the years. With the common pocket compass, it is the the needle that points north, and you rotate the housing to allign it properly. Even then, you don’t rotate the housing so the north pointing needle lines up with the “N”, but with true north minus the variation, the number you get from the maps, and which basically you memorize if you use the compass a lot. Because your maps are shown with true north orientation. In this way, the compass becomes a useful tool, despite the differences from true north being as great as a few dozen degrees! In aviation, doing this math was just too bothersome, so the practice began where everyone simply used compass bearings and not true bearings. Of course that often meant that as you flew into another region, the variation was different and the error to true north also different. But it didn’t matter, everyone, everywhere on the planet in aviation, used and still uses the magnetic bearings. In fact every runway in the world has a two digit number painted on the end for its magnetic compass heading, and all reference to that runway is by that heading. It becomes the very name of that runway. Tower will say, “cleared to land runway 22”, meaning you are cleared to land on the runway pointing to compass heading 220.

The simple answer to your question is that “NO. A compass does NOT point to the true north. Instead, it points to the magnetic north.” Before the widespread usage of GPS, we depended a lot on a compass for driving, navigation, etc. When using a compass and map to navigate, the angle between magnetic and true north has to be taken into account in order to orient the north of the map (true north) to the compass direction (magnetic north). This is called magnetic declination. ( Magnetic declination - Wikipedia) I am not quite sure if any BOY SCOUTs teach a lot of reading a compass and relating it to proper orientation any more, due to GPS availability. I spent a lot of time in learning about this in the Korean Army, which I served for 2.5 years as mandatory requirement. I believe that military still place importance of using a compass, just in case that GPS may not be available in an emergency. All the fond memories of old days and life got a lot simpler due to GPS… All the best   Compass and GPS, from Wikipedia

A magnetic compass must point to magnetic north. Since the north magnetic pole is somewhere in northern Canada, this means that your needle will be off by quite a bit depending on where in the world you are. You might happen to be due true South of the magnetic pole, in which case it and the true north pole line up and your compass is pointing the right way. Otherwise you need to consult a local map to find out what the error is and allow for it - it varies from place to place and also year by year, but quite predictably. A gyroscopic compass, on the other hand, will point where it’s told to point; the only issue is that it needs to be set from some reference point.

Depends what you mean by “true” and “show”. I’ll explain: By common definition, the true north pole of the Earth is the bit of the surface of the Earth where the celestial north pole is directly overhead. If you were standing on it, and looked directly upwards, you’d see Polaris. Therefore: “True North” is the direction towards that point on the horizon[*] that is directly below the north celestial pole (in a pinch, directly below Polaris). The “north-seeking” end of a compass needle points roughly in that direction most of the time. However, even in the best conditions, it does not point exactly there. What the needle points to is a magnetic north pole. Any magnetic north pole. The Earth’s magnetic north pole is slightly to one side of the “true north” pole. However, if you understand this, and you also know something about your latitude, then the compass is showing you where true north is by pointing a bit to one side of it. That is because “showing” and “pointing at” are different things.  [*] in the northern hemisphere. In the southern hemisphere, true north is the direction towards that point on the horizon that is directly above the north celestial pole. Not very useful, so we use the south celestial pole instead… and true north is the direction opposite to true south.

No, it looks to Magnetic North. True North is where the northernmost point of the Earth rotates around and is where all lines of longitude on a map come together. Magnetic North is where the lines of the Earth's magnetic field converge in the northern hemisphere, formed by the liquid metallic core moving within the Earth; the pole constantly shifts position over time. The needle on a compass is magnetically a south pole which is attracted to the north magnetic pole of the Earth. True North and Magnetic North are geographically close, but they are not identical.

Because the earth's core is magnetised. A compass needle aligns itself with the earth's magnetic field lines because that is a lower-energy state. Else there will be a turning moment on the needle. We call the end of the needle that points closest to geographic north “north”. The point on the earth's surface corresponding to magnetic North (a free needle points straight down) is currently in the Arctic near geographic north. It moves around, faster in current years. When I was at school it was further south near Baffin Island. In geologic time it can flip completely and be near the geographic south pole. The earth's magnetic field is thought to be due to fluid circulation in the outer liquid iron core. The phenomenon is not completely understood. Not all planets have a magnetic field - a compass won't work on the moon.

In California, a compass points east of true North. In New York, it points west of true North. Somewhere in between, it points to true north, at the moment. The magnetic pole is slowly moving, so the place where magnetic north coincides with true North isn’t fixed.

It aligns to the strongest magnetic field it can find in its vicinity. If there are no currents or magnets near it, it will align with the magnetic field caused by Earth. As it turns out, it won’t point to the geographic North (the point in the north that doesn’t move when Earth spins), but to the magnetic North, which is close but not exactly there.

A compass needle points north because the north pole of the magnet inside it is attracted to the south pole of Earth's built-in magnet. ... Now if the needle in your compass is pointingnorth, that means it's being attracted (pulled toward) something near Earth's north pole.

A magnetic compass points to the north magnetic pole, which is some distance from the North Pole. Charts are available to look up the angular correction magnitude and direction to correct that error. See Compass - Wikipedia

Q: Does a compass show the true north? A compass show true magnetic north for your vicinity.  from: 4H Forestry Invitational There are maps available for most areas that show the relationship between true geophysical north v,. north magnetic pole. Web sites such as Compass - Wikipedia show the proper use of the compass.

The Earth has natural magnetism, oriented roughly north and south. A compass needle is a magnet. Magnets have a natural property of aligning with other magnets. In the absence of other forces, a compass needle aligns with the Earth's magnetic poles.
A gyro compass points to due North. A Magnetic compass points to magnetic North. A fluxgate compass which operates off the magnetic field can be set to read in True or Magnetic.
No. It points to magnetic north which is often off of true north. There are charts that tell you how to correct for true north.
Magnets are attracted to the North magnetic pole which wanders around the Arctic region. read about magnetism Magnet Basics
